Name: Trapdoor
Description: A trapdoor is a hidden piece of code that responds to a special input, allowing its user access to resources without passing through the normal security enforcement mechanism.

DetectionMethods.Method: Automated Static Analysis - Binary or Bytecode
DetectionMethods.Description:
According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Inter-application Flow Analysis
		Binary / Bytecode simple extractor - strings, ELF readers, etc.

DetectionMethods.Method: Manual Static Analysis - Binary or Bytecode
DetectionMethods.Description:
According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Binary / Bytecode disassembler - then use manual analysis for vulnerabilities & anomalies
		Generated Code Inspection

DetectionMethods.Method: Dynamic Analysis with Manual Results Interpretation
DetectionMethods.Description:
According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Automated Monitored Execution
		Forced Path Execution
		Debugger
		Monitored Virtual Environment - run potentially malicious code in sandbox / wrapper / virtual machine, see if it does anything suspicious

According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Highly cost effective:
```

		Manual Source Code Review (not inspections)
	```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Focused Manual Spotcheck - Focused manual analysis of source

According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Context-configured Source Code Weakness Analyzer

According to SOAR, the following detection techniques may be useful:

```
		Highly cost effective:
```

		Inspection (IEEE 1028 standard) (can apply to requirements, design, source code, etc.)
	```
		Cost effective for partial coverage:
```

		Formal Methods / Correct-By-Construction

PotentialMitigations.Description: Always verify the integrity of the software that is being installed.
Identify and closely inspect the conditions for entering privileged areas of the code, especially those related to authentication, process invocation, and network communications.
